solution_line_template: Dino works {hours_job1} hours at a rate of ${rate_job1} an hour, which means that work pays him {hours_job1}*{rate_job1}=<<{hours_job1}*{rate_job1}={income_job1}>>{income_job1} dollars a month
Dino works {hours_job2} hours at a rate of ${rate_job2} an hour, which means that work pays him {hours_job2}*{rate_job2}=<<{hours_job2}*{rate_job2}={income_job2}>>{income_job2} dollars a month
Dino works {hours_job3} hours at a rate of ${rate_job3} an hour, which means that work pays him {hours_job3}*{rate_job3}=<<{hours_job3}*{rate_job3}={income_job3}>>{income_job3} dollars a month
Altogether, this means Dino makes {income_job1}+{income_job3}+{income_job2}= <<{income_job1}+{income_job3}+{income_job2}={total_income}>>{total_income} dollars a month.

You subtract Dino's expenses of {monthly_expenses} from this amount, meaning he has {total_income}-{monthly_expenses}=<<{total_income}-{monthly_expenses}={money_left}>>{money_left} dollars at the end of the month
